content.title: Understanding the Switch Drop (feed down + return up)
content.content:
Safety note (rig-safe): This lesson is for conceptual learning on training rigs. Never open or work on real ceiling roses/switches unless the circuit is safely isolated, proven dead, and you are trained/supervised.

In a standard 3-plate ceiling rose circuit, the switch acts like a simple bridge. Its job is to break or complete the **live** path. The live conductor travels down to the switch and back up again — that down-and-up journey is the **switch drop**.

### The bucket model (rose terminal groups)
Think of the ceiling rose as three labelled buckets:
- **Neutral group:** supply neutral + lamp neutral (neutral is not switched).
- **Loop group (permanent live):** supply live and any permanent live links/feeds (this group stays live when the circuit is energised, even if the switch is OFF).
- **Switched live group:** the switched live return and the lamp live (this group is only live when the switch is ON).

### The live journey (the story you must be able to say out loud)
**Loop group → COM → L1 → Switched live group → lamp live**

### Micro “core role map” (ultra-beginner)
In many training setups, the switch drop cable has **two insulated cores + CPC**.

**At the switch:**
- **COM = the feed down (permanent live from the rose Loop group)**
- **L1 = the return up (switched live back to the rose Switched live group)**

**At the rose:**
- The **feed-down core** belongs in the **Loop group** (because it is permanent live feeding the switch)
- The **return-up core** belongs in the **Switched live group** (because it becomes live only when the switch is ON)

### Identification / sleeving rule (non-negotiable)
In a switch drop, a core colour can be misleading (for example, a blue core used as the switched live return). **Any core used as live must be identified as live (brown) at BOTH ends (both terminations).**

### CPC rule (also non-negotiable)
The CPC must be continuous through the circuit and must be terminated at the ceiling rose and at the switch point (earth terminal/connector), even with plastic accessories.

### Quick dead inspection checklist (before any meter work)
Tick these off visually (and with a gentle tug check) before testing:
- No exposed copper outside terminals
- No “plastic-in” (insulation clamped instead of copper)
- Correct terminals used (Loop group vs Switched live group; COM vs L1)
- Brown identification present where a core is used as live (at both ends)
- CPC present and terminated at rose and at switch point
- Terminations are firm (gentle tug test)

content.title: Check Your Understanding: The Live Path

questions.questionText: Which terminal group in the ceiling rose provides the permanent live feed down to the switch?
questions.hint: It stays live even when the switch is OFF.

questions.questionText: Which terminal on a 1-way switch receives the permanent live feed from the rose?
What colour identification/sleeving must be applied to a core used as switched live (even if the core is blue)?
questions.hint: Any core used as live must be identified as live.

questions.questionText: If the switch is ON, trace the live path from the rose to the lamp live using terminal names/groups.
questions.expectedAnswer: Rose Loop group → Switch COM → Switch L1 → Rose Switched live group → lamp live
questions.hint: COM feeds the switch; L1 returns to the lamp path.

content.title: Worked Example (I Do): Mapping the Switch Drop Using the Bucket Model
content.given: Training rig: 3-plate ceiling rose + 1-gang one-way switch. The switch drop cable has two insulated cores and a CPC. You need the switch to control the lamp (not permanently feed it).

steps.description: Name the job in one sentence.
steps.result: Send permanent live down to the switch, and bring a switched live back up to feed the lamp live.

steps.description: Choose the correct ‘buckets’ at the rose for the two switch-drop cores.
steps.result: Feed-down core → Loop group. Return-up core → Switched live group.

steps.description: Choose the correct switch terminals for the same two cores.
steps.result: Feed-down core → COM. Return-up core → L1.

steps.description: Apply the identification rule (sleeving) before you call it ‘finished’.
steps.result: If any core used as live is not already brown, identify it as brown at both ends (especially the return-up switched live).

steps.description: State what happens to Neutral in this method.
steps.result: Neutral stays in the rose Neutral group; it is not taken to the one-way switch in this classic loop-in method.
CPC remains continuous and is terminated at the rose and at the switch point earth terminal/connector.
No exposed copper, no plastic-in, correct terminals used, brown ID present where needed, CPC terminated, gentle tug test passed.

content.notes: The whole goal is simple: the lamp live must only be fed from the Switched live group, not from the permanent Loop group.

content.title: Guided Practice (We Do): Same Workflow, You Fill the Blanks
content.problem: Training rig scenario: You are standing at the rose looking at the switch drop cable. You must decide: which bucket each core goes into, which switch terminal each core goes into, and what identification you must add so it’s unambiguous.

steps.prompt: Which rose terminal group (‘bucket’) must the feed-down core go into so the switch receives permanent live?
steps.hint: It must be live even when the switch is OFF.

steps.prompt: Which switch terminal receives that feed-down core?
steps.hint: COM = the input side of a one-way switch.

steps.prompt: Which switch terminal sends the return-up conductor back toward the lamp path when the switch is ON?
steps.hint: COM connects to this terminal when switched ON.

steps.prompt: Which rose terminal group must the return-up conductor go into so it feeds the lamp live only when ON?
steps.hint: This group is only live when the switch is ON.

steps.prompt: If the return-up core is blue, what identification must be added at the terminations?
steps.hint: Any conductor used as live must be identified as live.

steps.prompt: Name two items from the quick dead-inspection checklist you would confirm before meter work.
steps.hint: Pick any two: copper visibility, insulation clamped, tightness, CPC, correct terminals, brown ID.

questions.questionText: Where does neutral terminate in a standard 3-plate ceiling rose method: at the switch, or in the rose neutral group?
questions.hint: Neutral is not switched in this method.

questions.questionText: Name two quick dead-inspection checks you do on the switch terminations before any meter work.
expectedAnswer: No exposed copper and tug test
No exposed copper and check for plastic-in
Check for plastic-in and tug test
CPC present/terminated and no exposed copper
Brown ID present and no exposed copper
Correct terminal used and tug test
questions.hint: Think: copper visibility, tightness, insulation in the terminal, CPC, brown ID.

questions.questionText: True or False: If the switch plate and back box are plastic, the CPC can be left loose and unterminated.
questions.hint: Earth continuity must be maintained through the circuit.

questions.questionText: Misconnection check: If the return-up (switched live) conductor is accidentally placed into the rose Loop group instead of the Switched live group, what is the likely effect on lamp control?
expectedAnswer: The lamp may be permanently live
The switch may not control the lamp
The lamp live could be fed permanently
questions.hint: Think: Loop group = permanent live (always-live join).

questions.questionText: Explain the journey of Live, Neutral, and CPC from the ceiling rose to the one-way switch and back again, including where brown identification is required.
questions.expectedAnswer: Live feeds from the rose Loop group down to switch COM, then returns from switch L1 back to the rose Switched live group and feeds lamp live. Neutral stays in the rose Neutral group (not on the switch). CPC is continuous and terminated at rose and switch point. Any core used as live in the switch drop is identified brown at terminations (especially the return).
questions.hint: Use the bucket model and name COM/L1.

content.title: Spaced Review (from prerequisites)

questions.questionText: What is the standard colour for Neutral in a modern UK installation?
questions.hint: Brown = line, blue = neutral, green/yellow = CPC.

questions.questionText: What is the purpose of the Loop group in a 3-plate ceiling rose?
questions.expectedAnswer: To join permanent lives and provide the permanent live feed (including the feed to the switch).
questions.hint: It stays live even when the switch is OFF.

questions.questionText: Name the three terminal groups in a typical 3-plate ceiling rose.
questions.hint: Think: permanent live, return-to-lamp, and neutrals.

content.notes: Reinforcing the bucket model, conductor roles, and rig-safe inspection habits.
